content: The Act is titled the "National Infrastructure Improvement Act of 2004" and includes definitions. The "National Infrastructure Improvement Act of 2004" defines key terms related to infrastructure, including acquisition, commission, construction, and infrastructure itself. The term "infrastructure" refers to nonmilitary structures, facilities, and associated equipment, including surface transportation, mass transit, airports, water systems, and wastewater facilities. The term "maintenance" refers to regularly scheduled activities like routine repairs to ensure infrastructure operates efficiently. "Rehabilitation" includes correcting deficiencies, extending useful life, modernizing equipment, and replacing parts of existing infrastructure. The term "maintenance" refers to routine repairs for infrastructure efficiency, while "rehabilitation" involves correcting deficiencies, modernizing equipment, and replacing parts. This includes the modernization or replacement of rolling stock related to infrastructure. Establishment of Commission. The National Commission on the Infrastructure of the United States is established to ensure that the country's infrastructure meets current and future demand, and facilitates economic growth. The Commission will consist of 7 members appointed by the President, Speaker of the House, minority leader of the House, majority leader of the Senate, and minority leader of the Senate. The Commission members must have experience in economics, public administration, civil engineering, public works, planning, or public investment financing. Appointments should be made within 90 days of the Act's enactment. Members serve for the Commission's lifespan, and vacancies must be filled within 30 days in the same manner as the original appointment. The Commission must hold its initial meeting within 30 days of all members being appointed. Meetings will be called by the Chairperson or majority of members, with a majority constituting a quorum. The Commission will select a Chairperson and Vice Chairperson from its members. SEC. 4. DUTIES. The Commission will select a Chairperson and Vice Chairperson from its members. The Commission is required to complete a study on the state of the infrastructure of the United States by February 15, 2007. This study will include assessing the capacity of infrastructure improvements to sustain economic development, the age and condition of public infrastructure, and the methods used to finance infrastructure projects. The curr_chunk discusses the financing methods for public works improvements, including bonds, taxes, fees, and private investment. It also mentions trends in financing methods, investment requirements for facility maintenance and improvement, and the projected government investment shares. The Commission will consult with stakeholders including the Secretary of the Army, Secretary of Agriculture, Secretary of Transportation, and Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency to gather estimates on infrastructure investment returns, trends in procurement methods, and innovations in construction methods or materials. The Commission, in consultation with various stakeholders, including government officials and private sector representatives, will utilize existing resources and data to gather information for infrastructure investment analysis. The Commission will use existing studies, data, and reports to develop recommendations on a Federal infrastructure plan and public works improvements. They will also ensure that new data collection is done in consultation with States for uniform methods and analyses. The Commission will develop analysis criteria and procedures for inventorying, assessing, and reporting on public works improvements. They will submit a detailed statement of findings and conclusions to Congress by February 15, 2007. The Commission will provide recommendations for legislation and administrative actions over various time periods as deemed appropriate. The Commission has the power to hold hearings, gather information from federal agencies, accept gifts, and enter into contracts with other entities to conduct studies required by the Act. The Commission, under the guidance of the Act, may conduct studies and utilize postal services like other federal agencies. The Commission members serve without pay but receive a per diem allowance for travel expenses. The Chairperson can appoint an executive director and additional staff without following civil service laws. The executive director's employment is subject to confirmation by a majority of the Commission members. Compensation for staff is determined as necessary. The Chairperson of the Commission has the authority to set compensation for the executive director and staff without following certain federal pay regulations. The maximum compensation for employees (excluding the executive director) is capped at the rate for Executive Level IV. Federal Government employees can be detailed to the Commission without reimbursement, maintaining their civil service status. The Secretary of the Army can provide necessary support services to the Commission on a reimbursable basis. The Congressional Budget Office will review the report submitted by the Commission within 90 days. Funding for the Commission includes a transfer of up to $2,000,000 for fiscal year 2005 and an authorization of $1,000,000 for each of fiscal years 2006 and 2007. The Commission will terminate on September 30, 2007.
